prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Arguments rejected by the Panel—Alternatives to transfer

para.paratext: Parties frequently urge the Panel not to order transfer under § 1407 for the reason that there are alternatives that make transfer unnecessary. These arguments are occasionally successful, but they most often are rejected by the Panel.[1]

Probably the most frequently advanced alternative to transfer is the voluntary cooperation and coordination of the litigation among the parties. This argument has generally not been successful. In one case the Panel stated:

Though voluntary cooperation among the parties as a means of avoiding duplicative discovery is commendable, placing these actions under the control of a single judge will ensure that duplicative discovery on the complex factual questions will be prevented and have the salutary effect of eliminating the possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings.[2]

The Panel has, however, encouraged such voluntary cooperation and informal coordination in cases it determines are not appropriate for transfer.[3] The Panel has also suggested that it would not have ordered transfer if the parties had agreed on a discovery program and was ordering transfer, in part, because of the parties' failure to do so.[4] The decisions are thus not crystal-clear on what role this factor plays. The biggest problem with this argument is, of course, that the cooperation of the parties may be ephemeral. If the parties are, in fact, resolving their pretrial disputes without the necessity of court involvement, then transfer should have little impact on the process.

The Panel has frequently invoked “alternatives to transfer” as a explanation for not ordering transfer, but it has done so primarily when only a few cases are pending.[5] Where the number of cases is large, viable alternatives to transfer are not likely to exist.[6] The Panel has also noted that the fact that the parties in numerous cases were represented by the same counsel militated in favor of finding that “alternatives to transfer” exist.[7] The Panel has, however, found alternatives to transfer even in actions involving many parties.[8]

The Panel has also rejected arguments that transfer is unnecessary because the courts in which the actions are pending have consolidated them for coordinated or consolidated pre-trial proceedings before a single judge.[9] The cases considered by the Panel involve intracircuit coordination allowed under the Judicial Code.[10] The Panel has again found that transfer is appropriate for reasons related to the possible need for transfer if the in-place alternative ceased functioning as intended and because transfer would not undermine the process if it was working.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
The Panel's decisions relying on alternatives to transfer as a reason for denying transfer—whether argued by the parties or not—are discussed in § 5:33, above.

In re General Tire & Rubber Co. Securities Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1032, 1034 (J.P.M.L. 1977). See also In re Royal Alliance Associates, Inc., Securities Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Zurn Pex Plumbing Products Liability Litigation, 572 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re BP Products North America, Inc., Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 560 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Virgin Mobile Initial Public Offering (IPO) Securities Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Gadolinium Contrast Dyes Products Liability Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Aurora Dairy Corp. Organic Milk Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re H & R Block Mortg. Corp. Prescreening Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Pharmastem Therapeutics, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Mosaid Technologies Inc., Patent Litigation, 283 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Gator Corp. Software Trademark & Copyright Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Dow Chemical Co. Sarabond Products Liability Litigation, 650 F. Supp. 187, 189 (J.P.M.L. 1986).

See In re Raymond Lee Organization, Inc. Securities Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 1266 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Eli Lilly & Co. (Cephalexin Monohydrate) Patent Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 242 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Allen Compound Bow Patent Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 248 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Wyeth Patent Infringement Litigation, 445 F. Supp. 992 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Texas Instruments Inc. Employment Practices Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 928 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Southern Railway Employment Practices Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 926 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

See, e.g., In re Kauffman Mut. Fund Actions, 337 F. Supp. 1337, 1339 (J.P.M.L. 1972). See also In re Genentech Herceptin (Trastuzumab) Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2016) (Panel concludes that contentious relationship of counsel made voluntary cooperation an unlikely alternative to centralization).

See, e.g., In re Arthur J. Gallagher Risk Management Services, Inc., Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (3 actions in 3 districts); In re Medicare Fee Schedule Locality Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1344 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (2 actions in 2 districts); In re Best Buy Co., Inc., Restocking Fee Sales Practices Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (2 actions in 2 districts); In re Circuit City Stores, Inc., Restocking Fee Sales Practices Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (3 actions in 3 districts); In re Edward D. Jones & Co., Overtime Pay Litigation, 442 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (3 actions in 3 districts); In re Bank of America Fiduciary Accounts Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 2d 1349 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (2 actions in 2 districts); In re Highway Accident in Buffalo County, Nebraska, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (3 actions in 2 districts); In re Equicredit Corp. Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 276 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re DaimlerChrysler Corp. Seat Belt Buckle Products Liability Lit., 217 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (2 actions); In re W.E. Hall Co., Inc., Patent Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (2 actions); In re Pharmacy Ben. Plan Administrators Pricing Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (2 actions); In re Lawrence Moore/International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Litigation, 198 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (2 actions); In re Plasma Display Panels Patent Litigation, 196 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (2 actions); In re Chromated Copper Arsenate (CCA) Treated Wood Products Liability Litigation, 188 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (2 actions); In re Monochloroacetic Acid (MCAA) Antitrust Litigation, 187 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (2 actions); In re Eli Lilly & Co. (Cephalexin Monohydrate) Patent Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 242, 244 (J.P.M.L. 1978).

See, e.g., In re Air Crash over the Southern Indian Ocean, on March 8, 2014, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (alternatives not likely to be workable for a 40-case docket with more filings likely).

See In re Ocala Funding, LLC, Commercial Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1332 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Northeast Contaminated Beef Products Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Plavix Products Liability Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Bulk Mailing to County Jail Inmates in the State of Washington, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Ronald Beecher Estate Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Global Distribution Systems (GDS) Antitrust Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Oxycontin Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 395 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2005).

See, e.g., In re Northeast Contaminated Beef Products Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Plavix Products Liability Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Ronald Beecher Estate Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Global Distribution Systems (GDS) Antitrust Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Aegon USA, Inc., Supplemental Cancer Ins. Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (7 actions in 5 districts, but factual issues not particularly complex); In re Shoulder Pain Pump-Chondrolysis Products Liability Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (13 actions in 8 districts, but numerous factual differences in actions); In re Title Ins. Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) & Antitrust Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (25 actions, but different regulatory schemes in each state militate in favor of finding alternatives to transfer exist).

See, e.g., In re Women's Clothing Antitrust Litigation, 455 F. Supp. 1388 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Air Crash Disaster at Pago Pago, Am. Samoa, on January 30, 1974, 383 F. Supp. 501, 502 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Gas Vent Pipe Antitrust Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 799, 800 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
28 U.S.C.A. § 292(b). This statute is set forth in full in § 3:19.
